Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2009 07:35PM Irishred wrote: I had a biopsy on June 2 and was called with the results on June 4.  Still waiting to get into the surgeon.  And I feel like saying, DONT COME HERE RIGHT NOW.  Because I dont know what I need and when I do I will call you.  My tumor/s  are a lot bigger and faster than yours but since I went thru planned parenthood (becuase I am unemployed and have no ins) they are rolling this baby right along fast.  I expect to see a surgeon next week and hopefully an oncologist soon after.  My thinking is:  if its bad take it all no matter what,  i might consider radiation but i WILL NOT do chemo or hormone therapy.  and after watching my husband die of a rare form of cancer, I have to think QUALITY NOT QUANTITY.  Hope this helps,  e mail me if you want a great chart my daughter made for me.  cstupak@tampabay.rr.com

Posts.Title: Severe radiation burns to the breast RCindy

Posts.Content: Irishred wrote: OK guys, I went to the surgeon today, tuesday, my surgery is thursday (was hoping for a little more time to finish the kitchen and hall tiling job , i finished the tile but havent installed the moulding , but oh well)   I am having a "sentinel lumpectomy"  I havent read about this anywhere, they inject you with an isotpe and blue dye before surgery.  The Doc can SEE which lymph nodes have cancer cells so he doesnt have to remove all of them, like the old fashioned way.  This procedure can detect as little as "one" cancer cell.  Sounds better than whacking everything in sight to me.  I go in as an outpatient, surgery at 10:30 should be heading home by 2 pm.  Makes me think of getting your tonsils out, lol. But  I am hopeful, the Dr and his staff were great.  Gave me a ton of material to read and a teddy bear (so cute) Any way I am so lucky to have the support I do My sister will be with me for surgery and the three days after constantly.    Who knows thursday after surgery I might even feel like dealing poker (which i do for a living)  Any way,  if anyone has had this type of surgery IE. sentinel, let me know how it worked out.  Thanks Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled Irishred Kaidog

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 09:44PM Irishred wrote:
Posts.Title: Radiation Therapy and Itching shemei otlady49

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 07:40PM Irishred wrote: Hey,  I have been unemployed for almost 2 years ,  when I found my lump, I researched and went to Planned Parenthood.  The health dept here in central florida, has been absolutely wonderful.  My case manager, Clarence, got me straight Medicaid starting june 1, (retroactively) and everything is covered.  I am even with one of the best breast cancer surgeons in this area.  I have been treated wonderfully.  Not like I expected being on medicaid.  So  hopefully this will help others,  if financially burdened, GO TO PLANNED PARENTHOOD this will start the procedure to get good help for you at no cost.  Hope this helps. I am having a sentinel lumpectomy tomorrow so please put all of your wonderful thoughts out there for me.  One of my kids asked me today if I was nervous or scared, and I said NO, not really, this has to be done, I know the facts, I can do surgery and radiation if necessary, BUT I WILL NEVER DO CHEMO.  I definitely want Quality , not Quantity.  Hell, I want to play a million more poker games.  Lots of Luck to you.
Posts.Title: Refuse To Do Surgery makingway nelia48

Posts.Content: Irishred wrote: I have IDC, stage 3, have had lumpectomy with 8 nodes removed, the first two had tumor or cancer cells, the rest were clean.  Am having fluid retention at surgery site which needs draining once or twice a week.  The oncologist I saw today is  talking chemo and then radiation.  I am in charge of me, and I am not making any decisions untill I have all the facts.  But in reality, someone help me out here.  Tell me how many days, say from surgery thru 365 days including chemo, radiation or whatever treatment you had, did you feel like doing anything buy laying around the house, or maybe just very light housework.   I refuse to live the rest of what life I have left being sick and miserable. Even if I have chemo, no one can guarantee complete recoverey, thats not possible.  Just curious as to time tables others have experienced.  My ONC told me after about one and a half years I would start feeling back to normal.  Any info would be appreciated. Posts.Title: Loss of most of use of arm Irishred Irishred

Posts.Content: Irishred wrote: We are the ones going thru the torment and pain, right,  then I think its time the therapists, techs, and doctors start listening to US.  We are paying their bills right ?????  If you are not happy with something, SAY SO,  If you feel like some one is not doing their job, SAY SO.  After 4 rad treatments, I SPOKE UP, and wow what a difference it made in my treatment and health and well being.  SO  LADIES, WHO IS IN CHARGE HERE?   US OR THEM???  I will be in charge of me thru all of this and forever, I will make my own decisions, I will chose my treaments, and I will chose my care from the medical profession.  If I dont like something, and can't get it to change, then I will move on to another facility.  Speak up ladies, and get what you deserve,  compassion,  caring,  support and respect. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Who is the Boss here??? Irishred kane744

Posts.Content: Irishred wrote: Wow, it just hit me tonite how HUMBLING cancer is. I have always been the most healthy, most active, took care of everyone and everything, was never gonna die, was gonna live to at least 98, and within seconds, you realize, you had better be humble at this point in life.  I have a few more treatments to go,  and I am really going to appreciate going to visit my daughter and elderly aunt and uncle and at the end of that spending two nights beachfront in a great hotel at Cocoa Beach.  And then its back to the everyday grind.  I really believe we should be retired when we are young and then work till we die.  Then we could do and enjoy all the things we want while we are able.I have a great attitude,  and then I realize the doctors don't have a clue whether they "cured" you or not.  There really isnt a test that can prove that.They are just hoping like I do.  So, my goal is to enjoy everyday and every minute as much as I can,  and I hope you will all do the same.
